title: Churn Prediction in the Energy Sector
text:
Churn Model Dashboard


During my internship with the Boston Consulting Group (BCG), I led the development of a robust churn prediction framework for an energy service provider. The objective was to identify high-risk customers and enable proactive, data-driven retention strategies.



The energy sector faces increasing competition and shifting customer expectations. A rising churn rate posed a threat to customer lifetime value and operational costs. The challenge was to:

Detect customers likely to churn

Understand why they churn

Enable actionable business strategies for retention





The dataset consisted of over 10,000 anonymized customer records across 12 months, with features such as:

ğŸ“† Price history (monthly pricing plans)

ğŸ“ Service interaction logs

âš¡ Energy preference (clean vs.Â conventional)

ğŸ·ï¸ Demographics and usage behavior

â±ï¸ Tenure and contract type


I engineered 54 features after preprocessing, including volatility metrics, service score deltas, and churn flags.





Tools used: R, tidymodels, xgboost, vip, ggstatsplot, yardstick
Workflow:

Data preprocessing with recipes

Stratified train/test split using rsample

Model tuning with tune_grid and 5-fold CV

Model interpretation with vip, DALEX

Top model: xgboost (AUC = 0.91)




ğŸ¯ Volatility in pricing was a top predictor of churn.

ğŸš« Customers with inconsistent service touchpoints showed higher churn risk.

ğŸŒ± Customers preferring clean energy had lower churn probability, suggesting an opportunity for sustainability-aligned marketing.





Visuals were generated using vip, ggplot2, and ggstatsplot to support deep feature understanding and stakeholder presentations.





âœ… Delivered a complete churn prediction pipeline in R.

ğŸ“¦ Packaged the codebase for handoff to the client-side data engineering team.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ Presented results to consultants and client stakeholders with a focus on business alignment and interpretability.

title: Zero-Grazing Dairy Farm Management App
text:
Dairy App Dashboard


This project is a comprehensive Shiny web application designed to help zero-grazing dairy farmers manage their operations efficiently. Built as a modular SaaS solution, it covers the entire lifecycle of herd and resource management, promoting productivity, animal welfare, and sustainability.



Smallholder dairy farmers face challenges with recordkeeping, herd health monitoring, feed optimization, and financial tracking. Most rely on manual methods or outdated systems.

This application provides a data-driven digital platform to streamline farm management using an easy-to-use interface and powerful analytics.





The app includes 13 core modules:

ğŸ® Herd Management â€“ Animal tracking, health history, breeding records

ğŸ¥› Milk Production â€“ Quantity, quality, and milk sales logs

ğŸŒ¾ Feed Management â€“ Feed plans, consumption, and inventory

ğŸ’Š Medication & Inventory â€“ Stock control, treatments, alerts

ğŸ‘¥ Labor Management â€“ Staff assignments, time logs

ğŸ“ˆ Reports & Analytics â€“ Productivity charts, sustainability KPIs

ğŸ” User Access â€“ Role-based login, multi-tiered subscriptions

Additional features: - Responsive layout with modular Shiny structure - SQLite backend for offline-first storage - ShinyManager for authentication - Integrated dashboards using plotly and DT





Frontend: R + Shiny, shinymanager, bslib, shinyWidgets, shinyjs

Backend: SQLite, modular server logic, session management

Visualization: plotly, ggplot2, gganimate, DT, reactable

SaaS Design: Subscription logic, farm-based data partitions






ğŸ“Š Enables data-informed decisions at the farm level

title: Solar Cooker Performance Testing Platform
text:
Solar Cooker System


This project presents an open-source, low-cost solar cooker testing system aligned with the ASAE S580.1 standard. It combines sensor-based data acquisition, embedded electronics, and a web-based R Shiny dashboard to standardize cooking power evaluation and quantify sustainability impacts.



In many low-resource settings, solar cooking solutions lack affordable, standardized testing equipment, making it hard to validate performance or compare cookers. Traditional lab-grade equipment is cost-prohibitive, excluding local NGOs and researchers.





Microcontroller: Arduino Uno (ATmega328P)
Sensors:

DS18B20 digital temperature sensors for ambient and water temperature
BPW34 photodiode + PTFE cosine corrector for solar irradiance

Data Logging:

SD Card module for timestamped logs
RTC DS3232 for accurate timekeeping

Display & Feedback:

20x4 I2C LCD for real-time display
HC-06 Bluetooth for wireless transmission



The system reads, logs, and transmits temperature and irradiance data in real-time while calculating cooking power and standardizing it to 700 W/mÂ² per ASAE S580.1.








Shiny Dashboard Screenshot


The R Shiny dashboard provides:

ğŸ“ˆ Real-time data visualization
ğŸ“Š Cooking power analysis
ğŸŒ¿ Sustainability metrics (fuel savings, COâ‚‚ emissions avoided, health impact proxy)
ğŸ§¾ Downloadable reports in PDF or Excel





To ensure accuracy and repeatability:

Proteus 8 Professional was used to simulate DS18B20 and BPW34 sensor behavior
Potentiometers emulated dynamic temperature and irradiance in real time
System calibration ensured sensor readings aligned with empirical standards






âš¡ Empowers communities and NGOs to validate solar cooking technology affordably
ğŸŒ± Models environmental benefits (e.g., COâ‚‚ reduction)
ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ”¬ Supports academic and policy research through replicable, open-source methodology
